title: Smaller towns paying price for large cities swallowing up most foreign investment
text:
The flow of foreign direct investment towards the UK’s largest cities is fuelling economic disparity across the country as surrounding towns and villages are left short-changed, according to a report.

Overseas investment in the UK’s 12 largest cities has surged in recent years, rising from 31pc in 1997 to 59pc last year, but funnelling money to certain cities risks driving a “structural imbalance”, the report from EY and Centre For Towns, a research firm, suggests.

London has received outsized benefits versus other parts of the country, including major cities such as Manchester that the report called “core cities”, with the capital accounting for 457 out of 624 foreign direct investment projects...
